displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, is it a mail-order thing? And if it’s crazy, is there a different thing we can do? Uh, the other thing to say about Zytiga, is it’s going to be generic soon, but I’m not sure it, if we’re quite there yet. I’m not sure. I can find that out. But, uh, so if you tell me, geez, I really don’t want to take prednisone, then I would do the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Otherwise, I would do the Zytiga. Patient: Yeah. I don’t really want to take prednisone. I saw how it affected her. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: I’m L___. Doctor: His wife is L. Same last name? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And she works… Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In your hospital. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In PT?
FAM Um hum. (pause sending text) Doctor: Your phone will probably ring in thirty seconds. Doctor: Okay, so um… Family Member: And they don’t do any kind of surgery again to clean up margins or do any of that kind of stuff?
DOC That’s what radiation is for. Okay. Doctor: The question now is about starting your hormone shots.

Patient: disappear. Doctor: We need some red blood cells and I think I can corral some. He just has to be around you to get it. Patient: Right. If I didn’t have to scurry up on getting these pain meds today. Doctor: Well, I mean do you have to get them from there or can we just write them for you? Patient: I don’t know if you can just write me. If you just write them, you know, that would save me a trip. Doctor: Can’t we just write them? I mean it’s just because I mean a couple of things. You were there because we were trying to sort out what’s going on but you’re gonna be under our care more now because you’re going to be on the study… Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So why don’t we just write them for you? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Don’t you think? Because it’s like… Patient: That’s fine by me. Doctor: You’ve got, I mean you were scattered before because you weren’t really coming here… Patient: Right.

Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes. Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. But I feel like, um, D___ is in pain often, and, um, it’s, I would say the past two weeks, I would say like maybe last week, maybe a week and a half ago, he was in a lot of pain and very weak, from my perspective, what I am seeing. And, um, so often, and often would mean almost nightly, I am rubbing him with either Salonpas or Aspercreme or Bengay, one of the three, on his back, shoulders, legs, so that he can feel comfortable enough so he can lay down and rest. So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Patient: Did you get the results I emailed you. The DNA. Doctor: Yes. So, I got back the germline genetics testing. So this that this testing, well, do you remember? Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this. Patient: That’s different than this. Doctor: Yeah, because this this genotype that we're looking for- it does not predispose you to cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: This is something that's very common in the population. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We just think that these people are more likely to respond to antioxidants.

Family Member: And you just go holistic. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Yeah, you know, and then just keep up a good approach. Patient: I like that approach, you know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have to go and come back next week. Doctor: Okay. All right, well then, so you know what we can do then if you're if you're comfortable. Let me make sure that we went over everything too because Patient: I’m comfortable. That’s the way I am. Doctor: Let me go, let me just make sure you're a volunteer. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yeah, your participation will obviously not affect your clinical care. We're going to collect biospecimens as part of this so your blood, you can find this study online. We talked about the muscadine grape skin and that we don't know for sure if this works or not, that's why we're testing it and obviously we follow your PSA. So yeah, so 80 people total are going to be in it. Alright, so the first part that we need to do this pre screening is and we do need you to sign is to get the blood test drawn to see if you're eligible for it. So if you're agreeable to at least that part then we can do that today. Okay, all right. So this means that this at least then you won't be charged for the test. Do you want that? Patient: Yes.

Family Member: Actually that bread probably isn’t either. But then it tells you not to eat the whole grain stuff Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -after the radiation so we went to- Doctor: Well now you’re hopefully out of the hole. You know? You’re done with radiation. And I hope your back feels better. I hope. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Yeah. It’s a lot better. Doctor: Alright. Did you start on that XTANDI four pills? Did you start your extra pill recently? Family Member: He ran out, they didn’t send enough. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Family Member: So he took out that- Patient: Yeah. I explained to the doctor that- Doctor: Um hum.

Family Member: Never mind then. Doctor: Depending on the cryo if you decide to go with that and all of that and when Dr. C____ does it, then your next appointments will be changed Patient: Yep. Doctor: according to that. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Sound like a plan? Patient: Yeah it’s a plan. Patient: There he is. Doctor: Wow alright, thank you. I’ll be back. Hello. Patient: Hi. Doctor: Okay so any questions, any concerns? Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it.

Healthcare Professional: The paper towel looks like. Doctor: You said it’s okay? Okay. How are you? Patient: Hum, all right, except my neck hurts where that rod is. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, so you scored your pain a six. Was that for that pain or to the abdomen? Patient: Oh, that’s when, huh, they gave me the needle. I told her. Doctor: Okay. Good. But six isn’t your neck or-? Patient: Huh, I would say, sometimes it’s a five on my neck, especially when I turn it. Doctor: Okay. And so- Patient: Before, it was turning to the left and it was turning to the right because I wanted to start driving. But now, when I turn it to the left it seems like right there you can feel the bone. Doctor: So you’ve not been able to drive yet because you can’t twist your neck enough? Patient: Right. Family Member: And on your (voice)

Patient: Uh my legs you know uh there are a couple things we talked about Doctor: Um hum. Patient: what might be going on. Uh, you know, Dr. D___, I really like, he’s a good guy. Doctor: Good guy. Right? I thought you’d like him. Patient: And he, you know, he maybe suggested maybe uh arthritis. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: But it seemed like I, would have, I was degenerating pretty quickly for you know? For all the bone scans I’ve had… Doctor: Yeah. Yes. Patient: Somebody would have seen that somewhere. Doctor: No. I think it’s just crappy cancer not controlled. You know? Patient: And Uh. Yeah. Doctor: There’s, there’s the uh oh this is really going to be in trouble. We got that fixed. But it’s the bigger picture.

Family Member: Well, it does tell you stuff right away. Doctor: It does. (Pause) Patient: Is that a Hopkins web site, uh? Doctor: No, this is just Wikipedia. Family Member: Wikipedia? Doctor: I don’t, it sometimes has enough information that I can get quickly. Patient: Look at something else. Yeah. Doctor: I don’t see anything that says Patient: Maybe they’ll cover it on that TV show? So. Doctor: It says there’s only fifty cases worldwide. Patient: What??? Doctor: Severe deficiency.

Patient: Most of stuff I had looked up, and so it’s okay now. Now, does this drug actually kill the cancer? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It does? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So it’s almost like a chemotherapy? Doctor: Well, it’s like a super hormone. That’s really what it is. It sits in the hormone pathway, so, it’ll kill it like that. Family Member: Because you need the hormone to kill the cancer? Doctor: Yeah. Which is why it’s not going to be like you have hair loss and all that because it’s not a chemo, per se, but it’ll shut it down. Yep. Cool. Okay. All right. Patient: That’s about it. Doctor: Um hum. Keep the phone, not the paperwork. I’ll check my e-mail and see where we are, and if you have to go make some phone calls, C___, you’ll know what to do. Family Member: I need the pharmacy to call me or go harass somebody. Patient: Good luck with that. (Laughs)

Family Member: The pestering is what it is. Doctor: Yeah, you shouldn’t just sit on it. Family Member: That’s what I told him, I said it’s gonna fall off if you don’t do something. Laughs]] Doctor: No I don’t think, no but the things way more… Patient: Are we on tape right now? Ah, we’ll talk about that later. Doctor: No but I’m surprised, how many months have you been putting up with this? A lot of time? Like years? Family Member: No, no. Six months, eight months? Patient: One year – well yeah right in there. Family Member: But it’s gotten… Patient: Well it – that statin helps. Family Member: Yeah he showed me though and it is… Doctor: Yeah but that’s a temporary fix. Patient: I know. I know it.

Patient: How are you today? Doctor: Good timing. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I thought otherwise usually when I walk in you’re not here or something. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s how it works out. Okay how are you feeling? How are the joints and everything else? Patient: Yeah, it’s all – it’s all good. Doctor: That’s all okay? Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: That has not acted up or gotten worse in the last few… Patient: No, no. Not since I went back on the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve been fine since then.

Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Or my sense is the other thing is, you know, if time was short, I probably would sort of step back and sort of just focus on, you know, good days. Um. So I would sit there on the fence. I’m not ready to give up on myself. I wanna try something versus -- hhh this has all been too much. (Pause4sec) Patient: If it, it, it extends my, my time that I have to wait for a real cure then maybe it’s worth it. Doctor: Well, that reality is pretty slim. You know, we’ve been working on this awhile, and I’m not sure that a cure is gonna just pop up in the next six months, nine months. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And again, we often, er, don’t have drugs that resurrect people. Uh. You can hope. I hope and pray as well. Uh. The reality is, you know, you can keep pluggin’ along. Uh, so I think you’re eligible because you’re physically well enough to get through this. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? And you have the desire, uh, but there may be a point where I think you maybe too sick or your labs don’t work, or there are other things that suggest that more therapy is not the right thing. Patient: I see. Doctor: I will say that to you. It may not be what you want to hear. Patient: It’s the reality. (Pause) Doctor: As long as the quality’s good. That’s my worry. Okay? You can get extra time, but if it sucks, then it’s (not awful)
